data.title: New Hampshire Historical Society - Philippe, Louis (1773-1850)
data.meta_description: French nobleman, sympathetic to liberal cause during French Revolution. Exiled 1793, and spent the next 7 years in Europe and America, In several cases as a tea
data.text:
Name: Philippe, Louis (1773-1850)

Title: Duc d'Orleans

King of the French

Other Names: Louis-Philippe I, King of the French

Born: 10/06/1773

Birthplace: Paris, France

Died: 08/26/1850

Death Location: Claremont, Surrey, England

Residence: Paris, France

Reichenau, Switzerland

Muonio, Scandinavia

Boston, United States

Havana, Cuba

Nova Scotia

England

Nationality: French

Occupation: French noble

Teacher during exile

Father: Louis Philippe Joseph, Duc de Chartres

Mother: Louise Marie Adelaide de Bourbon-Penthievre

Relations: Friend of the Duke of Kent

Spouse: Marie Amalie de Bourbon-Sicilies

Marianne Banzori

Beata Caisa Wahlbom

Children: Ferdinand-Philippe, Prince Royal

Louise Queen of the Belgians

Marie d'Orleans, Duchess of Wurttemberg

Louis, duc de Nemours

Francisca d'Orleans

Clemintine, Princess of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha

Francois, Prince de Joinville

Charles, duc de Penthievre

Henri, duc d'Aumale

Antoine, duc de Montpensier

Erik Wahlbom (illigitimate)

Unnamed (Illigitimate)

Notes: French nobleman, sympathetic to liberal cause during French Revolution. Exiled 1793, and spent the next 7 years in Europe and America, In several cases as a teacher. Spent the 15 years from 1800 to 1815 in England, then returned to France. Served in the Courts of Louis XVIII and Charles X, then was pronounced the new French King in 1830. Reigned until abdicated 24 February ,1848, during the February 1848 Revolution. He was replaced by the Second Republic two days later. He returned to England where he died in 1850. Buried in Dreux.
